column2: Janice has a question. Who of the six of you has sleep with the six of\nyou?'
Wow, it\xc2\x92s like a dirty math problem.'
I\xc2\x92m sorry the answer there would be...none of us.'
Come on over the years none of you ever y'know, got drunk and stupid."
Well, that\xc2\x92s really a different question.'
I\xc2\x92m sorry I find it hard to believe that a group of people who\nspends as much time together as you guys do has never bumped uglies.'
Well, there was that one time that Monica and Rachel got together.'
What?!!'
Excuse me, there was no time!'
Okay, but let\xc2\x92s say there was. How might that go?'
Okay, okay, well then answer me this. Has any of you ever.... almost?'
Does anybody need more coffee?'
Yeah, I\xc2\x92ll take some.'
Hey, there\xc2\x92s a dog out there!'
Oh, that is so unfortunate.'
What?'
Cute naked guy is really starting to put on weight.'
(entering from bedroom) Okay, I\xc2\x92ll be back in just a minute. Oh,\nPhoebe I\xc2\x92m sorry that I left lipstick marks on the phone.'
You didn\xc2\x92t leave lipstick marks on the phone.'
Oh, then it must\xc2\x92ve been you. Bye. (leaves)'
(angrily) Bye-bye! (to Ross) That\xc2\x92s why I moved out.'
Hey, y'know while we\xc2\x92re on that, when are you gonna tell my sister\nthat you don\xc2\x92t live here anymore."
I think on some levels she already knows.'

Phoebe, she doesn\xc2\x92t know that you sneak out every night, she\ndoesn\xc2\x92t know that you sneak back every morning, and she doesn\xc2\x92t know that\nyou\xc2\x92ve been living with your Grandmother\xc2\x92s for a week now.'
Okay, well maybe not on those levels.'
(entering, with a goatee) Hey.'
Hey.'
I\xc2\x92m never gonna find a roommate, ever.'
Why, nobody good?'

Well let\xc2\x92s see, there was the guy with the ferrets, that\xc2\x92s
plural. The spitter. Oh-ho, and yes, the guy that enjoyed my name so much he felt the need
to make a little noise every time he said it. Nice to meet you, Chandler Bing Bing!
Great apartment Chandler Bing, Bing!'
So how many more do you have tomorrow?'

Two. This photographer, who seemed really dull. And this actor guy,\nwho I\xc2\x92m not sure about, because when he called and I answered the phone\n\xc2\x91Chandler Bing,\xc2\x92 he said \xc2\x91Whoa-whoa, short message.\xc2\x92'
(entering) Ross (who has his foot on the coffee table), foot on the\nfloor or come over no more!'
(to Phoebe) Sure, your dresser is missing but this she notices.'
What?'
I have to go. Yeah, Carol should be home by now, soo...'
Umm, how\xc2\x92s it going with you guys?'
Oh, better, actually. Y'know I-I-I think I finally figured out why we were\nhaving so much trouble lately."
Oh, really?'

Yeah, y'know how I have you guys, well she doesn\xc2\x92t really have any\nclose friends that are just hers, but last week she meet this woman at the gym, Susan\nsomething, and they really hit it off, and I-I-I think it\xc2\x92s gonna make a difference"
Soo, ah, Eric, what kind of photography do ya do?'
Oh, mostly fashion, so there may be models here from time to time, I hope\nthat\xc2\x92s cool.'
Yes, that is cool. Because I have models here y'know......never."

Oh, yeah, during the summer, I spend most weekends at my sister\xc2\x92s\nbeach house, which you are welcome to use by the way. Although, I should probably tell\nyou, she\xc2\x92s a porn star. (Chandler breaks his pencil in half)'

Well, listen I ah, still have one more person to ah meet, but unless\nit turns out to be your sister, I think you\xc2\x92re chances are pretty good. (Eric offers\nto shake hands) All right. (Chandler hugs him.)'
(running around the apartment pointing out things) Bedroom. Bathroom.\nLiving room. This right here is the kitchen, and thanks for coming by, (opens door)\nBye-bye.'
Don\xc2\x92t you ah, don\xc2\x92t you wanna ask me any questions?'
Sure. Ummm. What\xc2\x92s up?'
Well, ah, I\xc2\x92m an actor. I\xc2\x92m fairly neat. I ah, I got my own TV.\nOh, and don\xc2\x92t worry I\xc2\x92m totally okay with the gay thing.'
What gay thing?'
Ah, y'know just in general people being gay, thing. I\xc2\x92m totally cool\nwith that."
Well okay Jerry, thanks for stopping by.'
Hi.'
Hey!'
Hey, Mon.'
Hey-hey-hey. You wanna hear something that sucks.'
Do I ever.'
Chris says they\xc2\x92re closing down the bar.'
No way!'
Yeah, apparently they\xc2\x92re turning it into some kinda coffee place.'
Just coffee! Where are we gonna hang out now?'
Got me.'
(to bartender) Can I get a beer.'
Hey, did you pick a roommate?'
You betcha!'
Is it the Italian guy?'
Um-mm, yeah right!'
He\xc2\x92s so cute.'
Oh yes, and that\xc2\x92s what I want a roommate that I can walk around\nwith and be referred to as the funny one.'
Oh look, the pool table\xc2\x92s free. Rack \xc2\x91em up. I\xc2\x92ll be back\nin just a minute. Get ready for me to whip your butt.'
Okay, but after that, we\xc2\x92re shootin\xc2\x92 some pool.'

(sitting at a table with some of her friends) (to waitress) Oh, um, no,\nno, no, no excuse me, hello. Hi. My friend ordered an onion, not an olive, and uh I\nordered a rum and Diet Coke, which I don\xc2\x92t think this is.'
I am so sorry.'
That\xc2\x92s all right. (to her friends) I mean hard is it to get a\ncouple drinks right, huh?'
Well, I would like to propose a toast to the woman, who in one\nyear from today, become Mrs. Dr. Barry Farber DDS'
Ummm, I think it\xc2\x92s time to see the ring again. (holds her hand out\nand they all scream)'
Oh, isn\xc2\x92t it exciting, I mean it\xc2\x92s like having a\nboyfriend for life.'
Yeah, I know.'
What?'

Oh, I don\xc2\x92t know. Well maybe it\xc2\x92s just the idea of Barry for\nthe rest of my life. I don\xc2\x92t know I think I feel like I need to have one last fling,\ny'know, just to sorta get it out of my system. (Chandler is listening in very intensely)"
Rachel stop!'
You\xc2\x92re so bad!'
I\xc2\x92m serious, I really, I think I need just to have\nsome...meaningless, sex y'know, with the next guy that I see."
Excuse, I seem to have dropped my ball.'
Yeah, so?'
(picks it up) And now I\xc2\x92ve picked it up again. (walks over to\nMonica.)'
Oh my God, I went to high school with her. (to Rachel) Rachel! Hi!'
Monica! Look! Hi! What do ya think? (shows her, her ring)'
Oh my God, you can\xc2\x92t even see where the Titanic hit it.'
Yes, his name is Barry, he\xc2\x92s a doctor, thank you very much.'
Awww, just like you always wanted. Congratulations'
Thank you. So how-how \xc2\x91bout you, are-are you seeing anybody?'
Aww, not right now.'
Oh, but that\xc2\x92s okay.'
I know.'
Yeah.'
So, I\xc2\x92ll get-get back to my friend.'
Oh, yeah, sure, sure, sure, sure. (points at Chandler, who holds up the\ncue ball as a \xc2\x91Remember me?\xc2\x92 thing) Listen, can we please have lunch the next\ntime I\xc2\x92m in the city?'
Oh, that\xc2\x92d be great.'
Okay!'
Thanks.'
Bye!'
Bye! (to Chandler) Ten bucks says, I never see that woman again in my\nlife.'
No real-, honey, really it\xc2\x92s fine, just g-go with Susan. Really, I,\nno, I think girls night out is a great idea. Okay, okay, bye'
So what are they doing?'
I don\xc2\x92t know, something girlie.'
(to Monica, who\xc2\x92s entering) Hey, you\xc2\x92re early.'
What are you doing with the lamp?'
I\xc2\x92m just taking it to be re-wired.'
Oh, well don\xc2\x92t take it to the same place you took the stereo,\n\xc2\x91cause they\xc2\x92ve had that thing for over a week.'
No, no, Mr. Heckles no one is making any noise up here.'
You\xc2\x92re disturbing my oboe practice.'
You don\xc2\x92t play the oboe!'
I could play the oboe!'
Then I\xc2\x92m gonna have to ask you to keep it down. (slams the door in\nhis face.)'
(to Eric) Who are you?'
Hi, I\xc2\x92m Eric, I\xc2\x92m gonna be Chandler\xc2\x92s new roommate.'
I\xc2\x92m Chandler\xc2\x92s new roommate.'
I-I-I don\xc2\x92t think so.'
I could be Chandler\xc2\x92s new roommate.'
But, he told me over the phone.'
He told me in person.'
That\xc2\x92s weird.'
Well, I\xc2\x92m going to go into my new apartment now. (goes over to\nthe door and opens it) Ehh! (Eric leaves)'
Hi, again.'
Hey! (goes into the apartment)'
(leaving to go to work) Hey!'
Thank you soo, much.'
Oh, don\xc2\x92t thank me, thank the jerk that never showed up. Okay, I\ngotta get to get to work.'
You want some help with that?'
Oh, no thanks, I got it. (picks it up) No I don\xc2\x92t!'
Whoa! Are you okay?'
Whew! Stood up to fast, got a little head rush.'
It\xc2\x92s the heat. (has her hand on his chest, and then pulls it away)\nAnd-and the humidity.'
That\xc2\x92s a uh, that\xc2\x92s a tough combination.'
Do you wanna come in for some lemonade?'
Like you wouldn\xc2\x92t believe. (they go into the apartment) Wow! This is\na great place.'
Thank you. Just make yourself comfortable.'
Gotcha.'

This place is really my Grandmother\xc2\x92s. (Joey starts to take off all
of his clothes, while Monica gets the glasses and pours the lemonade.) I got it from her
when she moved to Florida, otherwise I could never afford a place like this. So if the
landlord ever asks, I\xc2\x92m 87 year old woman, who\xc2\x92s afraid of her VCR. So are you
thirsty?'
Oh, you bet I am!'
(turning around) Okay, here\xc2\x92s your penis!'
Oh my God!!! What are you doing?!!'
You said, you wanna come in for some lemonade?'
So?!'
Whoa, ah!! We\xc2\x92re you just gonna give me some lemonade?'
Yeah huh!! Cover yourself up!'
Oh right, right.'
I don\xc2\x92t believe this! When someone asks you in for lemonade, and to\nyou that means they wanna have sex?'
Well usually...yeah! Well, not just lemonade, iced tea, sometimes juice.\nWell, sorry, I just, I thought you liked me. I\xc2\x92m such a jerk.'
It\xc2\x92s okay. I suppose it could happen to anyone, not anyone I know,\nbut... By the way I can still see it.'
Pheebs?'
Huh?'
Where\xc2\x92s your bed?'
It\xc2\x92s not in the apartment? (Monica gives a \xc2\x91Come on\xc2\x92\nlook) Oh no. I can\xc2\x92t believe this is happening again.'
What?'
Okay, enough with the third degree! I-I\xc2\x92ve, I don\xc2\x92t live here\nanymore.'
What are you talking about?'
I\xc2\x92m sorry, I-I-I-I don\xc2\x92t live here anymore. I-I didn\xc2\x92t\nknow how to tell you, but y'know everybody else knows!"
Everybody knows!'

That was supposed to be a good thing, I forget why. Just listen, Monica,\nI, do you know, okay, do you know, I couldn\xc2\x92t sleep for like a month because I got\nlike a dot of ink on one of the sofa cushions. '
Well, you-you coulda just turned the cushion over.'
Yeah, I would\xc2\x92ve except I had a big spaghetti stain on the other\nside.'
What?!?!'
Okay, this is what I\xc2\x92m talking about, this. I-I need to live in a\nland where people can spill.'
You can spill. In the sink.'
Aw, honey it\xc2\x92s not your fault, y'know this is who you are, and I\nlove you, and I want us to be friends, and if I keep living here I don\xc2\x92t see that\nhappening."
I love you, too. '
Aww, good. (they hug) What?'
What? I\xc2\x92m just said.'
No you\xc2\x92re not, you\xc2\x92re wondering which cushion it is.'
So ah, whatcha watching?'
Baywatch.'
What\xc2\x92s it about?'
Lifeguards.'
Well, it sounds kinda stupid... (looks at the TV) Who\xc2\x92s she?'
Nicole Eggert. You'll like her."
Wow! Look at them run.'
They do that a lot. Hey, you want a beer?'
Yeah, I\xc2\x92ll go get one.'
No, no, no, don\xc2\x92t get up, I got a cooler right here.'
Well, hello!'
Hey.'
Do you have any beers? We\xc2\x92re out of beers.'
(all depressed) Help yourself.'
You okay?'
Phoebe moved out.'
Right.'
I don\xc2\x92t understand, I mean am I so hard to live, is this why I\ndon\xc2\x92t have a boyfriend?'
Noo!! You don\xc2\x92t have a boyfriend because....I don\xc2\x92t, I\ndon\xc2\x92t know why you don\xc2\x92t have a boyfriend. You should have a boyfriend.'
Well, I think so.'
Oh-ho, come here. (goes and hugs her) Listen, you are one of my\nfavourite people and the most beautiful woman I\xc2\x92ve ever known in real life.'
(all depressed) Hi. Where is everybody?'
Oh, it\xc2\x92s already closed, Chris gave me the keys to lock up-what is\nwrong?'
My marriage, I think my marriage is um, is kinda over.'
Oh no! Why?'
\xc2\x91Cause Carol\xc2\x92s a lesbian. (Phoebe is shocked) And, and I\xc2\x92m\nnot one. And apparently it\xc2\x92s not a mix and match situation.'
Oh my God! I don\xc2\x92t believe it! Oh, you poor bunny.'

(sets out a bunch of shot glasses and starts to poor himself a drink, many
drinks) I\xc2\x92m an idiot. I mean shoulda seen it, I mean Carol and I\xc2\x92d be out and
she\xc2\x92d, she\xc2\x92d see some beautiful woman, and, and she\xc2\x92d be Ross y'know look
at her, and I\xc2\x92d think, God, my wife is cool!"
Aw! Hey, do you think that Susan person is her lover?'
Well, now I do!!'
I\xc2\x92m sorry.'
Seven years. I mean we\xc2\x92ve been together seven years, she\xc2\x92s the\nonly woman who\xc2\x92s ever loved me, and the only woman I\xc2\x92ve-I\xc2\x92ve ever....'
Aw, God Ross. Oh.(goes over and hugs him)'
Umm, this is nice.'
I know, it is isn\xc2\x92t it?'
No, I mean it, this feels really good. Is it a hundred percent cotton?'
Yeah! And I got it on sale, too.'
Anyway, I should go, one of the lifeguards was just about to dismantle\na nuclear device.'
Well, if you wanna get a drink later we can.'
Oh yeah, that sounds great. (starts to leave) Oh, and listen,\nit\xc2\x92s, it\xc2\x92s gonna be....'
I know. Thanks. (Chandler leaves)'
Maybe this would\xc2\x92ve happened if I\xc2\x92d been more nurturing, or\nI\xc2\x92d paid more attention, or I... had a uterus. I can\xc2\x92t believe this!'
I know no, no, y'know you don\xc2\x92t deserve this, you don\xc2\x92t Ross.\nYou\xc2\x92re, you\xc2\x92re really, you\xc2\x92re so good. (kisses him on the cheek)"
Thanks.'
And you\xc2\x92re so sweet. (kisses him on the other cheek) And\nyou\xc2\x92re kind (kisses him on the lips)'
Thanks. (kisses her on the lips)'
Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait.'
Huh?'
Okay, it\xc2\x92s okay.'
Oh. (they start kissing again)'
Wait, wait, wait.'
What?'
My foot is stuck in the pocket.'
What?'
No, I can\xc2\x92t get it out.'
Well, that\xc2\x92s not something a girl wants to hear.'
No, come on don\xc2\x92t start. (they start kissing again) Ouch!'
What?'
Stupid balls are in the way. (holds up two balls)'
Oh well. It probably would\xc2\x92ve been the most constructive solution.'
You have chalk on your face.'
Huh? (the rest of the gang enters)'
Oh, Ross you\xc2\x92re right, I don\xc2\x92t know why I always thought this\nwas real grass.'
Hey, are you okay?'
My wife\xc2\x92s a lesbian.'
Cool!!'
Ross-Joey, Joey-Ross. (they shake hands)'
Hi.'
I can\xc2\x92t believe you came back.'
Don\xc2\x92t say anything. I don\xc2\x92t wanna speak, I don\xc2\x92t wanna\nthink. I just want you to take me and kiss me and make love to me right here, right now.'
Rachel! Rachel! (stirs Rachel from her dream, she\xc2\x92s in her\ncar driving back from the city)'
What?'
You missed the exit!'
Oh, sorry.'
My God, what were you thinking about?'
Um, (shyly) Barry.'
Awwww!!'
